title: How to Make a Shofar

steps.headline: Fill the horn with water to check it for leaks.
steps.description: If there are cracks or leaks in the horn, it is not acceptable to be used as a shofar, according to Jewish law and tradition.

steps.headline: Kosher animals are those that have split hooves and chew their cud.
steps.description: For the purpose of making a shofar, use either the ram's horn or antelope.

steps.headline: Place the horn into a roaster or other large pan, and cover the horn with water.
Boil the horn for 2 to 5 hours or until it is soft and you can remove the internal cartilage.
steps.description: Use a kitchen pick, such as those used to remove nuts from their shells, to clean the horn and make it hollow. If you do not have a pick, any thin object that can reach into the small spaces may be used to clean the shofar.

steps.headline: Thread a wire through the horn to measure the depth of the hollow space inside.
steps.description: Allow the horn to dry completely.

steps.headline: Measure 1 inch (2.54 cm) past the end of the hollow area, and mark that point on the horn.
steps.description: Cut the tip of the thoroughly-dried shofar horn off at the mark.

steps.headline: Drill a 1/8-inch (.32 cm) hole through the cut end of the shofar.
Carve a mouthpiece on the shofar horn, similar to that of a trumpet.
steps.description: Fit the mouthpiece to the individual who will blow the shofar during its liturgical use.
